channel.title: How To Fix the Moderator Problem
channel.description:
This is just an attempt to split discussion of "the moderator problem" that I believe started around [url=http://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/topic,406501.msg3004269.html#msg3004269]here[/url] so we can let c|p have his thread back.
So, let us commence discussion about the moderator's job, whether it is being done up to the standard that people expect, and if not, suggestions on how it can be improved. And let's be nice about this; there's no need for a flame war. To prevent such a thing, let's leave out names. Address the staff as a whole, because it is supposed to work as one unit.
The goal, obviously, is to reach some compromise that can satisfy both ends.

item.title: How To Fix the Moderator Problem
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Arguing or debating through the PM system is fine. The reality though is that some of you guys are trying to masquerade as innocents when you aren’t. Truth be told, most of the private messages that are reported either involve advertisement (and other forms of unsolicited messages), or bullying.

Why should we tolerate bullying?
The bottom line: Calling people all sorts of derogative names, swearing at them, belittling them, invading their privacy, and having others join you in systematic emotional/mental attacks on them – these are all forms of bullying and, given the nature of some users (they’re young and very impressionable), it’s not something that we can let slide.
Hell, it wouldn’t slide in a workplace filled with adults, because even there people would find it entirely unacceptable; you’d have some committee (or a boss) so far up your arse that if they spat then it’d be coming out of your mouth.

I have a simple policy when dealing with people (unless I’m talking to a friend in which case the rules change): If you wouldn’t remain unscathed after saying it to someone in a pub/club after 11pm then it’s probably something that you shouldn’t say.
